questions.question_text:
You have a custom API that is secured by using Azure Active Directory (Azure AD).
You need to call the API from within a SharePoint Framework (SPFx) web part.
Which object should you use to call the API?

comments.content: i think it's B too, in another similar question it was AadHttpClient..

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Wrong Answer, Should be AadHttpClient
Both A & B are correct - However , as MS graph already been regards as new API frameworks and AAD APIs already been part of MS Graph framework. So the answer should be A.

questions.question_text:
You plan to deploy a SharePoint Framework (SPFx) solution to the tenant app catalog.
Which attribute should you configure in the package-solution.json file to ensure that the solution is available immediately to all site collections?
questions.answer_description:
You can configure your SharePoint Framework components to be immediately available across the tenant when the solution package is installed to the tenant app catalog. This can be configured by using the skipFeatureDeployment attribute in the package-solution.json file.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sharepoint/dev/spfx/tenant-scoped-deployment

choices.C: the TeamsTab value to the supportedHosts property in the manifest file
choices.B: a manifest file to the Teams folder in the solution
choices.D: a manifest file to the webparts folder in the solution
choices.A: the TeamsTab value to the componentType property in the manifest file

discussion.content: It is showing as answer D, but the explanation supports option C (supportedHosts)

I disaggree with C, because if you don't include the manifest file, it won't work (regardless of if you put the TeamsTab)
Moreover, if you think on the logic of the question, to make a teams tab work you could also chose to add TeamsPersonalApp on the supportedHost! (instead of answer C)

Thus it makes the C answer "not a requirement", whereas manifest file IS a requirement for the app to work.

comments.content:
see this link
https://www.c-sharpcorner.com/blogs/how-to-use-sharepoint-framework-spfx-in-teams-to-build-an-app

I think the answer is B in the end. Not D

discussion.content: It's C, the manifest can appear in the webpart project, but it can also be created outside the project. The supportedHost can only be done from the webpart project.
Why is it not C. the TeamsTab value to the supportedHosts property in the manifest file?

questions.question_text: What should you add to a SharePoint Framework (SPFx) solution to ensure that the solution can be used as a Microsoft Teams tab?

questions.answer_description:
Yeoman helps you to kickstart new projects, prescribing best practices and tools to help you stay productive. Using the Yeoman SharePoint generator, developers are able to scaffold new client-side solution projects to build, package, and deploy SharePoint solutions. The generator provides common build tools, boilerplate code, and a common playground website to host web parts for testing.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sharepoint/dev/spfx/toolchain/scaffolding-projects-using-yeoman-sharepoint-generator
questions.question_text: Which tool can you use to generate a SharePoint Framework (SPFx) solution?

discussion.content: Correct answer is D, submitted permission request has to be approved

choices.A: Create a SharePoint security group and add the solution

questions.answer_description:
Developers building a SharePoint Framework solution that requires access to specific resources secured with Azure AD list these resources along with the required permission scopes in the solution manifest. When deploying the solution package to the app catalog, SharePoint creates permission requests and prompts the administrator to manage the requested permissions. For each requested permission, tenant administrators can decide whether they want to grant or deny the specific permission.
All permissions are granted to the whole tenant and not to a specific application that has requested them. When the tenant administrator grants a specific permission, it is added to the SharePoint Online Client Extensibility Azure AD application, which is provisioned by Microsoft in every Azure AD and which is used by the SharePoint Framework in the OAuth flow to provide solutions with valid access tokens.
questions.question_text:
You have a line-of-business API that is secured by using Azure Active Directory (Azure AD).
You deploy a solution to the app catalog. The solution requests permission to the API.
What should you do in the SharePoint admin center to ensure that the solution can access the API?
